comments.body:
Is the order relevant here?

Previously, `destroyCSIDriver` ran first, then `driver.CleanupDriver`. Now it is the other way around.
Order doesn't entirely matter, but conceptually this new order is cleaner. We should delete the CSIDriver CRD before deleting the actual driver pods.

				}

comments.body: Can we add `driver.CleanupDriver()` here instead of in the `AfterEach` to be consistent with the create?
Can do.
does this test then verify that the volume/pod is in the correct topology?

It implicitly verifies by ensuring both positive and negative tests pass. I wanted to avoid inspecting topology details and instead focus on the end user's experience, which is whether or not a volume is available under different topology constraints.

comments.body:
this function makes some significant assumptions:
1) Driver is deployed with Daemonset
2) Driver is deployed with *strictly* 1 Daemonset
3) No other non-driver Daemonsets deployed

I am not sure these are reasonable assumptions to make for arbitrary drivers

Should it work for arbitrary drivers? I expect it to be used only in kubernetes e2e to test the Kubernetes part. I expect that each driver will have its own assumption how and when it can be updated.

If some generic mechanism is required (is it?), I can implement new `TestDriver` method to update a driver.

maybe it doesn't have to but its worth calling out in a comment, any function written might get "resused" in some other code without true understanding of what it does just based on the function name.

This part is failing on our external GCE PD tests as we bring up one driver in the default namespace as opposed to one in every test namespace. I wonder if maybe we can get the daemonset from a config specified namespace instead of using the test namespace. What do you think?

Also this test should be marked `[Serial] [Disruptive` if we make that change since it may affect usage of a shared driver.

/cc @msau42
Yes those sound like good enhancements
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/71527

Did not mark as serial or disruptive because the k8s tests are not disruptive. And I don't think the external tests respect the "Disruptive" flag anyway (?). We should make sure the external CI is running tests serially anyway because of this test
Do we need to wait for detach too?
Added wait for PVC deletion, that should wait for detach.
this is where claim size should be coming from right? xref: that comment i made in `setupResource`
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/69441#discussion_r224188265

comments.body: This prevents running tests in parallel, was that already the case?
Nope. I don't see a way out of a CRD installation race condition so I'll go ahead and mark it serial, and leave a TODO to remove it when CRD is installed automatically
Is it allowed to add it at the beginning of the suite instead of for each test? If so that's a better option.

Not AFAIK. There's `SynchronizedBeforeSuite()`:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/e7eb26919b8ebd2b1c86e58cdfc4f7db1edf4c2e/vendor/github.com/onsi/ginkgo/ginkgo_dsl.go#L496

but it can only be set once and it's already set here:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/e7eb26919b8ebd2b1c86e58cdfc4f7db1edf4c2e/test/e2e/e2e.go#L137

Given that we aim to have a generic CRD auto-install solution for different CRDs, I don't think it's worth the effort to devise a CRD installation mechanism in this function that reference specific tests, only to have it removed in the next release.

@kubernetes/sig-testing are there any other suggestions for installing CRDs once before any tests in the suite are run in parallel? Otherwise making the tests Serial might be our best bet
the problem is deletion right? Could we just not delete the CRD's from the cluster or would that cause issues...?
this function name is overloaded with the `csiTestDriver` Interface definition in the same file. I don't think its doing the same thing, can we change the name or fold it into the hostPath driver?
Yeah I'll be updating the e2e test again in a couple of days and could include this in that PR.

why do these tests need to be serial? AFAIK they weren't changed?

CRD creation can happen in the other context "CSI attach test using HostPath driver [Serial][Feature:CSISkipAttach]" Since that's all that would need it.

Adding on to that, is there any way to generalize the tests you wrote below in ""CSI attach test using HostPath driver [Serial][Feature:CSISkipAttach]" to work for all drivers in this suite? It's kind of awkward to have this very general framework up here and then a random feature test with just hostpath below it. If it has to be only hostpath, then I would recommend putting it in a different file `csi_hostpath_attach.go` for example
cc @jsafrane who wrote the test
Doesn't this add [Serial] in two distinct places in the test name? I don't believe the whole suite needs to be serial, just the new tests you added

We do need the whole suite to be serial - all e2e tests depend on the CRD if either the `CSINodeInfo` or `CSIDriverRegistry` is set, since drivers can't be registered without the CRD.

It's definitely an oversight though to have [Serial] in two places. Will fix that in my subsequent PR
if we're creating a new driver per test, how do these behave in parallel?
I commented [here](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/69868#discussion_r228686103) too, I think we need to run pd csi driver tests in serial.

@msau42 

Thank you for your answer. 
Is my understanding correct that it is also true for all the csi drivers including csi-hostpath?

Then, I will add ```[Serial]``` to test execution logic in csi_volumes.go instead of each ```TestDriver```'s ```FeatureTag```.
@pohly is in the process of making hostpath parallelizable, so only gce pd needs to be serialized.

comments.body: Should not true be in quotes? Since it is map[string]string..

```
type storageClassTest struct {
	name           string
	cloudProviders []string
	provisioner    string
	parameters     map[string]string
	claimSize      string
	expectedSize   string
	pvCheck        func(volume *v1.PersistentVolume) error
	nodeName       string
	attach         bool
	volumeMode     *v1.PersistentVolumeMode
}
```
Got it, by some reason, I thought it was part of `parameters` map.
Should not true be in quotes? Since it is map[string]string..
This is kind of weird. It seems like a case of silently swallowing a failure? Will this effectively ?keep these tests disabled until 62561 is resolved?
The test will get skipped if we can't find the secrets, until 62561 is resolved there's really no other way to do this unless you would rather have the test be red instead of skipped.
Sounds good. Once that happens let's remove this completely.
typo: `create`?
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/60840

Resource "nodes" need Verbs "update" from Line 423;
Resource "volumeattachments" need Verbs "delete" from Line 351.
This is policy for external-attacher started as a pod somewhere in this PR. It's not policy for the test itself.
@jsafrane Got it.
Any plans to also test mount/unmount, attach/detach?
Right now, we would need a driver that supports attach/detach. But mount/unmount is tested by `testDynamicProvisioning()`.

Actually, now that I think about it, the test does test it. It all depends on the driver, but the e2e test does send out all the CSI calls to attach/detach and mount/unmount. All the CSI drivers we have right now do attach/deatch and mount/unmount on the `NodePublish/Unpublish` calls done from the kubelet to the CSI driver. Probably when we get CSI drivers for the cloud vendors, the test would exercise attach/detach done from the `external-attacher` side car container to the CSI driver, then mount/unmount would be done by the kubelet to the CSI driver.

So, tldr: Yes, both are tested.

Now that I think about it, maybe I should change the text on line 227 to say something like: `should provision, attach/detach, then mount/unmount storage with a hostPath CSI driver`. Would that make sense?
I'd appreciate a constant for `10*time.Minute`, as it is used on multiple times
